column4: I'm trying to install ubuntu netbook remix, and have gotten to the partitioning stages, and I am a little stuck. I keep reading about logical partitions online, but don't see the options to create one - is a single primary partition set to ext3, boot at /, 75 GB, enough to continue?
make a extended partition and then create logicals from it
I am unclear on the steps to do so - I have created the partition I mentioned before, but see no option or button to create a logical within the installer
you make a extended partiton from your last primary (only 4 primarys are allowed) it will occupy all the remaining space, then you can resize the extended into smaller logicals .

the eeepc comes with 4 primaries already - /dev/sda1 is ntfs, /dev/sda2 was ntfs, is now ext3, /dev/sda3 is fat32 (?) and /dev/sda4 is not labeled, and I'm not touching it. When I try to lower the partition space of ext3, I end up with unusable space. How or when do I create logicals? Is it the next step in the installer? Or is there some piece of magic that I am missing?

well i have a Acer aspire netbook sda1 and sda2 are windows junk, i defragged the sda2 then resized it,then i used the unallocated space as ext3 extended, then i made two smaller partitions from it as logicals, i used gparted to do this.
i think there is a 5gb sdax not sure if it was sda3 or so i left it alone.
I seem to have the same sdax
I am still very unclear on this step - "then i made two smaller partitions from it as logicals"
i used a livecd of gparted to resize and to make the extended and then the logicals from it
the extended is the free space from resizing the sda2, it is made into a extended, then you can make logicals from it.
I already have it formatted in extended, and see no options for logicals anywhere - not in edit partition section, nor anywhere else
is it safe to sinply hit forward?
the extended free space from resizing the sda2 for me was about 25gb, i then made a couple 22 logicals and one swap from the extended.
I have 60 gb fro, the resizing of sda2
you probably should google for a howto gparted there are all kinds of em out there and can give you different ideas on how to proceed.
the idea of having to get another usb to load another program to be able to install ubuntu is depressing
well i guess i did make it easier by using a external usb dvd player and a cd with gparted live. i dont think ubuntu comes with gparted, you would of had to install it.
I am poor - I cannot afford an external dvd player
well i guess the best thing is get more knowledge, you can try google , you should be able to find some excellent howto's
n8tuser is willing to take you further into this, good luck....
thanks for the help (the reason I came here is because some of the how tos didn't explain certain steps, and I am currently stuck on the logical part)
